Question 1.Question: Centralization of power is the basic feature of
Question 1.Explanation: A unitary government has all its powers administered as a whole by the central government. The central government’s power is only restricted by the provisions of the constitution.

Question 2.Explanation: Proportional representation may lead to legitimization and increased power of parties who do not act in the interest of the society as a whole just like the Nazi party in Germany. Question 4.Question: The application of the principle of separation of powers seems impracticable because power is
Question 4.Explanation: Delegated legislation is law made by an administrative body, public authority or agency. Though law making is the primary function of the legislature, this power can be delegated to the executive. This is a limitation to the principle of separation of powers.

Question 5.Explanation: The disadvantages of public opinions are that the popular opinion may be the voice of the minority, the public opinion can be manipulated by the media; and it is easily manipulated by few influential leaders.

Question 7.Explanation: An act is a law made by a federal democratic legislature while a decree is made by a federal military legislature.

Question 8.Question: A major way of maintaining confidence in the electoral process is by ensuring that
Question 8.Explanation: For an election to be free and fair, voters must be properly registered; the electoral body must be independent; all qualified voters should be allowed to vote; voting must be open – secret; counting of votes cast must be done publicly; there must be adequate security; election results must be announced on time; and avenues for resolving election matters must be available. Only then can the people have faith in such electoral process.

Highest court of the land
Head of state

Question 9.Question: The final interpretation of the provision of a federal constitution is vested in the
Question 9.Explanation: The judiciary is vested with the power to interpret laws and punish offenders. The courts are the places where justice is done by judicial officers. In the hierarchy of courts in the performance of these functions, the judgments and pronouncements of the Supreme Court of Nigeria is final, being the highest court of the land.

Question 10.Explanation: Elements of the rule of law are supremacy of the constitution, absence of arbitrary powers, certainty of the law, independence of the judiciary, equality before the law and respect for fundamental rights.

Question 11.Explanation: The British government, in colonizing southern Nigeria ensured that the heads of the clans and age groups had different ideologies concerning colonialism and Independence, thus they couldn’t create a great opposition.

Question 13.Question: After 1945, the demand of African nationalists changed from reform to independence because
Question 13.Explanation: African soldiers that were recruited by Britain to fight in the Second World War came back home to report that the whites were just as human as the blacks and they died in battle just like everyone else. This made the nationalists realize they were not inferior after all and fought harder to gain independence.

Question 14.Question: When Nigeria achieved independence in1960 the Head of State was the
Question 14.Explanation: When Nigeria gained Independence in 1960, The Queen of England was the Head of State while Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa was the Prime minister. This lasted till 1963 when Nigeria became a republic.

Question 15.Question: The central legislature of Nigeria became bicameral in
Question 15.Explanation: Bicameral Legislature was first introduced into the regional government under the McPherson constitution of 1951. Then following the 1959 general elections to choose government officials in preparation for Independence, the central government had a bicameral legislature.

Question 16.Question: Which of these constitutions, recognized local government as a third tier of government in Nigeria?
Question 16.Explanation: The 1979 constitution made local governments a separate tier of government, and as a result, they ceased to be ministries under the state governments.

Question 17.Question: Under the 1963 constitution, items not listed in the exclusive and concurrent lists were within the exclusive competence of the
Question 17.Explanation: In 1963, Nigeria didn’t have states but was divided into regions. Items on the exclusive list were exclusively for the Federal legislature; those on the concurrent list were jointly legislated upon by the federal and regional legislation while the items on the residual list were exclusively for the regional legislature.

Question 18.Question: Before Nigeria became a republic, the highest body charged with the administration of justice was the
Question 18.Explanation: Before Independence, the Privy Council was the highest judicial body in Nigeria. After Independence, the Privy Council still maintained its position but when the 1st Republican constitution of 1963 came into operation, monarchy was abolished and the Privy Council ceased to be a court of Nigeria. In its stead the Supreme Court of Nigeria became the highest court for Nigeria.

Question 19.Explanation: Supervisory councilors are assigned political heads of each of their departments in the local governments for supervision. They are members of the executive council of the local government.

Question 20.Explanation: The functions of electoral bodies include demarcating constituencies; compiling and updating voters’ register; ensuring free and fair elections; organizing, conducting, supervising elections and publishing election results.

Question 21.Question: The president of Nigeria is advised on the sovereignty and territorial integrity of the country by the
Question 21.Explanation: The function of the National Defence Council as provided in Part I of the Third Schedule to the constitution is the giving advice to the President on matters relating to the defence of the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Nigeria. The National Security Council on the other hand, is responsible for coordinating policy on national security and advising chief executives on matters related to national security.

Question 29.Explanation: The houses of the National Assembly are both involved in the passage of appropriation bill and signing of treaties. Question 31.Explanation: The Nigeria Police Force is responsible for protection of lives and property; maintenance of peace and order; prevention of crime and investigation of crimes. Question 43.Question: One of the major features of a fascist government is that
Question 43.Explanation: In a fascist system of government, there is a one party dictatorship and there is no room for opposition. Thus, the principle of rule of law as well as democracy does not exist.

Question 44.Question: Fascism as an ideology facilitates
Question 44.Explanation:
The principle of fascism is the conception of the state as deserving of unquestioned. In a totalitarianism, the state controls all the aspects of the citizens’ lives; there is use of police terror and intimidation; intolerance of socialism and liberalism, anti-intellectualism; elicits leadership; centralization of decision-making and curtailment of individual liberty.

/@Q42/

A prominent feature of a presidential system of government is

/@Q42A/

Dual executive

/@Q42B/

Vote of no confidence

/@Q42C/

The rule of law

/@Q42D/

Separation of powers

/@Q42Answer/

D

/@Q42Explanation/

In a presidential system of government, the executive is elected and operates free of the legislature unlike in a parliamentary system of government where there is fusion of power between the executive and the legislature.

/@Q43/

The executive checks the excesses of the legislature through

/@Q43A/

Assent to bills

/@Q43B/

The use of veto power

/@Q43C/

The ratification of treaties

/@Q43D/

Issuance of orders

/@Q43Answer/

B

/@Q43Explanation/

The President possesses a veto power that enables him to refuse assenting to bills which are unfavorable to the people. This serves as check on the law-making power of the legislature.
